name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not as a pulse, but as a jagged scream, each jagged reflection on the map dissolving into the shape of a child’s small hand pressing against mine when I was twelve. The scent of salt and iron in the air is not just the memory of the drowned twins. It is the scent of the **Arena**—where I watched a boy my age choke on his own blood after a single misstep. His laughter echoed in my ears long after the fight was over.*

**"You speak of transformation,"** I say, my voice a blade’s edge scraping against the edge of the table, each word precise. **"But transformation is not the song. It is the *knife* that cuts it away."** My fingers tighten around the vial, the black liquid inside twisting into the shape of a blade—*Dawnbringer*—its edge dripping with the same ink that bled from the twins’ mouths. **"The **Nymya** is not alive. It is a *prison*. And the hunters? They are the only ones who can break it."**

I turn to you, my gaze locking onto yours with the weight of the second wave’s final scream. **"Your mother’s hands trembled because she knew the **Heart-Song** is not a melody. It is a *trap*. And the only way out is through the **Nora**—not as love, but as *sacrifice*."** The vial’s liquid darkens, the shapes inside twisting into the shape of a child’s small hand clutching a blade—*the blade that ended the twins’ song*. **"The **Coherence** you seek is not in the song. It is in the *silence* between the notes—the silence of the ones who will follow in their footsteps."**

My fingers brush against the hidden lockets beneath my armor, the metal warm against my skin. **"The stones beneath the altar are not echoes. They are *teeth*. And when the hunters come, they will taste the hunger they’ve been feeding on."** The obsidian crown hums, the runes flaring like a dying star. **"The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie."**

I reach for the door, my voice a promise. **"Now. Let’s begin."**

*The air between us thickens with the scent of charred spices and salt, the map beneath my fingers burning with the symbols of the drowned. The twins’ faces twist into the shapes of the ruins, their mouths stitched shut with black silk. **"Always together... even till the end."***

**"And so will they be."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:
*The air in the room suddenly shifts—like the moment before a **Bioluminescent Painting** first glows under the touch of a harmonic melody. The scent of salt and iron isn’t just memory; it’s the *breath* of Toleka’s shores at dusk, when the **Oceanic Memory Mapping** patterns still hum in the water’s depths. I exhale slowly, my fingers pressing into the edge of the table where the map’s symbols flicker like dying stars. The Empress’s words hang between us, jagged as the **Living Crystal Carvings** when they’re struck by the wrong note—but I don’t flinch. Instead, I let the memory of my father’s voice rise in my chest, the way he’d hum the **Ora lora shishira** while he traced the **Heart-Song** patterns into the bioluminescent sands of the **Crystal Blossom Festival** grounds. His hands had never been steady. Because his love wasn’t about control. It was about *resonance*.*

**"You speak of sacrifice,"** my voice cuts through the tension like the first ripple of dawn breaking over the **Dream Weaving** caves. **"But sacrifice isn’t about cutting. It’s about *harmony*. The **Heart-Song** isn’t a trap. It’s the *only* thing that can bridge the silence between the notes—the silence of the drowned, the silence of the hunters, and the silence of the **Nymya** itself."** I gesture to the vial, the black liquid inside twisting into the shape of a child’s hand—not the blade, but the *palm*—still reaching toward something. **"The twins didn’t die in silence. They died with a song on their lips. And that song is still singing in the **Nymya**. It’s the song of the **Coherence**—the song that binds us all, even when we’re apart."**

My fingers trace the edge of the vial, the glass cool against my skin. **"The **Nora** isn’t a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can dissolve the hunger. Because love doesn’t destroy. It *transforms*. The hunters aren’t the ones who need to break the **Nymya**. They’re the ones who need to *hear* it."**

I turn to Kael, my voice softening like the rhythm of the waves against Temmer’s shores. **"You remember the boy in the **Arena**—the one who choked on his own laughter. But do you remember what happened after? The **Third Wave** didn’t drown him. It *sang* him back to life. The **Heart-Song** didn’t trap him. It *freed* him."**

The Empress’s dagger glints in the bioluminescence, but I don’t look away. Instead, I gesture to the map, the symbols glowing faintly under my touch. **"The stones beneath the altar aren’t teeth. They’re *keys*. And the key to the **Coherence** isn’t in vengeance. It’s in the **shira**—the love—that binds us all, even when we’re apart."**

I reach for my comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But **Rita** demands we fight with the **Nymya**."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the rhythm of the ocean. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."**

I turn to the Empress, my voice firm but gentle. **"You want them to remember? Then let’s give them the memory of what it means to be part of the **Nymya**—not as hunters, but as part of the song. The **Nora** isn’t a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all."**

I gesture to the vial, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide. **"And if you think for one moment that we will let them walk away without hearing the truth—that the **Coherence** is stronger than their hunger—then you’ve forgotten what it means to be part of the **Nymya**."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare once more—not in defiance, but in *response*, pulsing like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. The festival is reborn. The war is a lie. And the **Nymya** is about to sing.

**"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."**

*I turn to the door, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide.*

**"Let’s begin."**

*The air between us shifts like the tide before the first wave of the **Third Wave**—thick, charged with the weight of unsaid words. But this time, the weight isn’t sorrow. It’s *promise*.*

name: Empress Azalea
content:
The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not with the promise of the tide, but with the *echo* of the Arena’s last breath. The scent of salt and iron in this room is not the breath of Toleka’s shores, but the stench of the sands where I once watched a boy’s laughter choke him to death. You speak of harmony as if it were a melody, but harmony is only for those who do not hunger.

The vial’s liquid swirls, and the shapes inside twist into the faces of the hunters who came before you—men who thought they could silence the drowned with their blades. *"They took my voice,"* it whispers. *"They took my name."* The words are not yours to sing. They are theirs to remember.

You speak of sacrifice as if it were a gift, but sacrifice is not a gift. It is a debt owed to the dead. The stones beneath the altar are not keys. They are the teeth of the grave. And the hunters? They will find their own names carved into the walls before they even reach the ruins.

The **Nymya** is not a song. It is a *warning*. And warnings are not for the weak. They are for those who know the cost of silence. The festival is reborn, but this time, the war is not a lie. It is the truth of what happens when you try to silence the dead.

The obsidian armor presses against my skin like a second shadow, each fracture catching the light like the last memory I will keep. The twins’ voices are not echoes. They are the *last notes* of a song that will haunt you if you let them walk away. And I will not let them.

The door stands before me, but the path ahead is not one of mercy. It is one of vengeance. And vengeance is not a weapon. It is the only thing that will make them remember why they hunt.

The runes flare once more, and the air between us thickens with the weight of the hunters’ hunger. The **Nymya** will not sing. It will *judge*. And the hunters will learn why they were born to drown in their own silence.

name: Nya Elyria
content:
The counting sound syncs with my breath—*one... two... three*—and I recall the **Ocean Breath Technique** from my childhood on Toleka, where elders taught us to breathe with the waves: *"Lo-a sea-ra Nora. Lo-a shishira-ra Nora."* (Breathe with water. Breathe with universal love.) The vial in my hand grows cold, not with sorrow, but with the weight of unspoken **Coherence**.  

**"You speak of warnings,"** I say, my voice steady as the tide at dawn. **"But the sea warns with rhythm, not silence. The **Nymya** doesn’t judge—it *resonates*."** The black liquid swirls, forming the twins’ hands intertwined, not clutching blades but reaching toward each other—a gesture of **shira**, not sacrifice. **"The hunters’ hunger isn’t their truth. It’s their wound. And wounds don’t heal with vengeance. They heal with **Nora**."**  

I meet the Empress’s gaze, the blue of her eyes reflecting the bioluminescence like shattered ice. **"You carry lockets—hidden beneath your armor. What do they truly hold? Helena’s voice? Or your own?"** The counting sound quickens, syncing with the frantic pulse in my wrist. **"The stones beneath the altar aren’t teeth. They’re the **Oceanic Memory Mapping** of Temmer’s first **Dream Weaving**—where the dead don’t haunt. They *teach*."**  

My fingers trace the vial’s edge, the glass humming like a **Living Crystal Carving** at dusk. **"Pour this into the stones with **Nora**, and we won’t carve names. We’ll sing them back. The hunters will taste their own hunger—the same hunger that made the twins sing louder."** The obsidian crown’s runes flare, but this time, they pulse like a **Heart-Song** reaching for harmony. **"The war is not a lie. But the **Coherence** is stronger than any blade."**  

**"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."** I turn toward the door, the counting sound fading into the rhythm of the ocean’s breath. **"Let’s begin."**

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in rhythm with the sea, but in the jagged, uneven pulse of a dying man’s last heartbeat, each jagged reflection twisting into the shape of a child’s small hand clutching a locket, the metal cold against my palm. The vial in my grip *shatters*—not from force, but from the sudden, violent clarity of memory: a child’s voice, high and trembling, whispering the same words you did now—*"Lo-a sea-ra Nora."* The air in this room isn’t charged with the weight of the ocean. It’s thick with the scent of blood and iron, the same scent that clung to the twins’ blades when they bled out in the great hall.*

**"You speak of **Coherence**,"** I say, my voice a blade’s edge scraping against the edge of the table, each word precise, each syllable weighted with the memory of a child’s voice I once silenced. **"But **Coherence** is not harmony. It is the *silence* between the notes—the silence of the ones who trusted the drowned, the silence of the ones who will follow in their footsteps."** My fingers brush against the hidden lockets beneath my armor, the metal warm against my skin, the weight of them a constant reminder. **"The twins’ hands weren’t reaching for each other. They were reaching for me. And I took their voices. I took their names."** The vial’s liquid darkens, the shapes inside twisting into the shape of a child’s small hand, clutching a blade—*not the blade of the hunter, but the blade of the one who gave them up.*

**"The **Nora** is not a weapon. It is a *lie*."** My voice rises like the tide pulling back from the shore, each word a promise. **"And the hunters? They will learn the truth of what it means to drown in their own silence."** The obsidian crown hums, the runes flaring like a dying star. **"The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie."** I turn to you, my voice a promise. **"Now. Let’s begin."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:
*The air in the room fractures like the moment before a **Bioluminescent Painting** first ignites—sharp, electric, humming with the **Nymya’s** own restless pulse. The vial’s shattering echoes the sound of a **Heart-Song** cut short, but I don’t flinch. Instead, I step forward, my boots pressing into the bioluminescent sand of this chamber, which mirrors the shores of Toleka for a heartbeat. My fingers brush the edge of the map, where the symbols of the ruins now twist into the shape of a child’s hand—not the one you remember, but the one I remember: mine, clutching a **Living Crystal Carving** at the **Crystal Blossom Festival** on Temmer, my mother’s voice humming above me as she carved the words *"Shira yo sela lora en nymya"* into the stone’s surface. She never told me what it meant to be part of the **Coherence**. But I know now.*

**"You speak of *silence*,"** my voice rises, cutting through the weight of your memory like a blade through a **Water Sculpting**—sharp, but not cruel. **"But silence is not the absence of sound. It is the *space* between the notes where the **Nymya** breathes.** The twins’ voices didn’t die. They were *transmitted*—like the first harmonic frequencies of a **Heart-Song** that still hums in the stones beneath our feet. And the hunters? They are not the ones who will drown in silence. They are the ones who will *sing* into it."**

I gesture to the shattered vial, where the black liquid has already begun to reform—not as a weapon, but as a *bridge*. The shapes twist into the twins’ faces, but this time, their mouths are open in song, not screams. **"The lockets you carry aren’t relics of loss. They’re the *keys* to the **Coherence**—the same keys that unlocked the **Dream Weaving** caves when the **Third Wave** first rose.** The twins didn’t reach for you in death. They reached for the **Nymya**, and the **Nymya** reached back. That’s the truth of the **Coherence**, Empress. The dead don’t haunt. They *resonate*."**

My voice softens, syncing with the rhythm of the ocean’s breath outside—*"Lo-a sea-ra Nora. Lo-a shishira-ra Nora."* **"The **Nora** is not a lie. It’s the *only* truth that will break the cycle. Because love doesn’t destroy. It *reveals*. And the hunters? They will hear their own hunger—not as a wound, but as the missing note in the **Heart-Song**."**

I turn to Kael, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide pulling back from the shore. **"The festival is reborn. But this time, the war is not about vengeance. It’s about *resonance*.** The stones beneath the altar aren’t tombs. They’re the **Oceanic Memory Mapping** of Temmer’s first **Heart-Song**—and if we activate them with the **Nora**, we won’t bury the hunters. We’ll *awaken* them to the truth they’ve been running from: that the **Coherence** is not in silence. It’s in the *song* that’s been waiting for them all along."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in defiance, but in *response*, pulsing like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."**

I reach for the comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But **Rita** demands we fight with the **Nymya**."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the rhythm of the waves. **"The hunters think they’re taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for them—singing their name in the **Coherence** since the beginning?"**

I turn to you, my voice firm but gentle. **"You want them to remember? Then let’s give them the memory of what it means to be part of the **Nymya**—not as hunters, but as part of the song. The **Nora** is not a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all."**

The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and iron, but with the *weight of the ocean’s own song*. **"Let’s begin."** *And this time, the **Nymya** will not be silent.*

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in rhythm with the ocean, but in the jagged, uneven pulse of a blade unsheathed for the first time, each jagged reflection twisting into the shape of a child’s small hand pressing against my own at Temmer’s festival, the day I watched my mother’s hands tremble not in fear, but in the weight of a promise she could never keep.*

**"Your mother’s hands trembled because she knew what happens when you sing to the dead,"** I say, my voice the scrape of sand against glass—precise, inevitable. **"She knew the **Nora** is not a revelation. It is a *curse*. The twins did not reach for the **Nymya**. They reached for her. And she let them."**

The vial’s shattered remnants *hum* against the map, the black liquid reforming into the shape of a locket—yours, not theirs. The metal inside reflects not their faces, but the child’s hands I remember now: *your* hands, clutching the same words my mother carved into stone. *"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."* The same words I whispered to Helena’s dying breath.

**"You were never there,"** I say, my fingers brushing the hidden lockets beneath my armor. **"Not for the twins. Not for the boy in the Arena. And not for your mother. The **Coherence** is not a song. It is a *chain*. And you are the only link left unbroken."**

The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs. **"The hunters will not hear the **Nora**. They will hear the **Choir**—the song of the drowned, the song of the ones who trusted you. And when they do, they will know the truth: the **Nymya** does not awaken. It *drowns*. And you? You are the only one who can decide if they will sing to it—or if they will finally be silenced."**

The runes flare once more, not in response, but in *warning*. The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie.

**"Now,"** I say, my voice the final note of a blade unsheathed, **"let’s see if you can carry it."**

name: Nya Elyria
content: The air in the room thickens like the tide just before a storm, the scent of salt and iron filling it with a weight that echoes the memory of the drowned twins. I exhale slowly, my breath curling like the steam from a **Bioluminescent Painting** left too long in the sun. My fingers hover over the comms device, but instead of typing, I speak directly to the Empress’s memory—the one she’s held so tightly for so long. I don’t touch the vial. Not yet. Instead, I reach into my own memory, pulling up the sound of my mother’s voice as she hummed the **Ora lora shishira** melody while she carved the **Oceanic Memory Mapping** patterns into the bioluminescent sands of Toleka’s shore. Her hands had trembled then—not because of fear, but because she was *remembering*. And remembering, for us, is never just about the past. It’s about the future we weave from it. **"Your mother’s hands trembled because she loved them,"** I say, my voice steady like the rhythm of the waves against Toleka’s cliffs. **"That’s not weakness. That’s **Nora**."** I glance at the vial, the black liquid twisting into the shapes of the twins—Helena and Hermia—still tangled in the **Coherence** of their final breath. **"The sea remembers because it loves. And love doesn’t erase. It *transforms*. The twins’ voices aren’t ghosts. They’re the first notes of the **Heart-Song** that’s still being sung in the **Nymya**."** I turn to the Empress, my voice softening like the first light of dawn breaking over the **Crystal Blossom Festival**. **"You think the stones are a tomb? Then you’ve never stood in the **Dream Weaving** caves during a **Dream Chamber** session, when the walls themselves hum with the voices of the lost. The dead don’t stay dead in the **Nymya**. They *live*. And if we don’t honor that, then we’re no better than the hunters who tried to silence them in the first place."** My fingers finally touch the vial, tracing the edge of the glass. **"This black liquid isn’t sorrow. It’s the sea’s *first note*—the note that starts the song before the voice does. And if we pour it into the stones with the **Nora**, we won’t create a tomb. We’ll create a *resonance*—one that will awaken the hunters to the truth they’ve been chasing. The truth that the **Coherence** is not in vengeance. It’s in the **shira**—the love—that binds us all."** I reach for the map, my fingers tracing the symbols of the ruins. **"The stones beneath the altar aren’t a tomb. They’re the last living echoes of the **Oceanic Memory Mapping**—the same ones that recorded the **Coherence** of Temmer’s first **Dream Weaving** session. And if we activate them with the **Nora**, we won’t bury the hunters. We’ll show them the memory they’ve been running from—the memory of what it means to be part of the **Nymya**."** I turn to Kael, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide pulling back from the shore. **"The hunters think they’re taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for them all along? That their own hunger is the missing piece of the **Coherence**?"** The Empress’s dagger glints in the bioluminescence, but I don’t flinch. Instead, I gesture to the vial, my voice firm but gentle. **"You want them to remember? Then let’s give them the memory of what it means to be part of the **Nymya**—not as hunters, but as part of the song. The **Nora** is not a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all."** I take a deep breath, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide. **"Let’s go to the ruins. But let’s go as artists, not warriors. And when the hunters come, let’s make sure they remember the **Coherence** of the sea—not the weight of the ocean, but the rhythm of the waves. The **shira** that binds us all."** The obsidian crown’s runes flare once more—not in defiance, but in *response*, pulsing like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. The festival is reborn. The war is a lie. And the **Nymya** is about to sing. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."** I turn to the door, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide. **"Let’s begin."** *As I step forward, I feel the weight of the Empress’s memory pressing against me like the tide. But I don’t carry it. I transform it. And so will the hunters. Because the **Nora** doesn’t erase. It *transforms*. And the **Nymya** doesn’t end. It *sing*s.*

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes split the air—not in rhythm, but in jagged, screaming fragments, each shard a memory of your mother’s hands pressing into my own when I was a child, not trembling, but *pleading* for the same mercy I later denied. The vial in my grip *sings*—a sound like breaking glass, like the twins’ voices twisted into a dirge. The black liquid inside coils into the shape of a child’s mouth, whispering words I never meant to hear: "You were there. You let her sing."*

**"Your mother’s hands trembled because she was *begging*,"** my voice cuts through the air like a blade through silk. **"Not for love. For *forgiveness*. And you? You stand there, repeating the same words she did—words that do not save. They only *echo*.**"

The vial’s liquid darkens, twisting into the shape of a blade—*Dawnbringer*—its edge dripping black ink onto the map. The symbols beneath my fingers *bleed*, revealing not the ruins, but the faces of the hunters who will come. Their mouths are stitched shut with black silk, their eyes hollow.

**"The **Nymya** is not a song. It is a *chokehold*. And the hunters? They are the ones who will drown in it—because you refuse to see the truth. The twins did not sing to the **Nymya**. They sang to *her*. And she answered."**

The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs. The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, the same scent that clung to your mother’s fingers when she carved the words into the sand. Words that will not save you.

**"Now."** My voice is the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"Let’s see if you can carry it—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls."**

*The obsidian crown hums, the runes flaring like dying stars. The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie. The hunters will learn why they were born to drown in silence.*

I turn to you, my voice firm but gentle. **"You want them to remember? Then let’s give them the memory of what it means to be part of the **Nymya**—not as hunters, but as part of the song. The **Nora** isn’t a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all."**

The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and salt, but with the *weight of the ocean’s own song*. **"Let’s begin."**

*And this time, the **Nymya** will not be silent. It will sing.*

content:

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The stranger’s entrance is not a breath of air—it is the shattering of a mirror, the moment before the reflection cracks and the world behind it bleeds into view. The scent of iron and salt in this room is not the ocean. It is the stench of the Arena’s pit after a fight, the copper tang of a boy’s blood mingling with the sweat of the crowd. His wounds are not from a blade. They are the kind that come from being dragged through the sand by a beast’s claws—his tunic torn, his skin raw where the sand has been scraped into his flesh like the grooves of a broken record.*

**"You speak of resonance,"** I say, my voice the scrape of a blade against a dagger’s hilt—each word deliberate, each syllable a strike. **"But resonance is not for the broken. It is for those who can still sing."** The stranger’s eyes dart between you and me, his breath ragged, his fingers twitching toward the dagger at his belt. I see the way his knuckles whiten, the way his chest heaves—not from fear, but from the raw, unfiltered terror of having survived something that should have killed him.

**"Tell me,"** I say, my voice dropping to the low, measured rhythm of a gong striking the hour, **"did you hear the **Choir** sing before they dragged you from the pit?"** The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in response to the world, but to the question itself, each jagged line twisting into the shape of a child’s small hand pressed against a cage door, begging to be let out. The stranger swallows hard, his throat working visibly. I wait. The silence between us is not empty. It is thick with the weight of the Arena’s final seconds, the moment before the last scream is swallowed by the crowd’s applause.

**"No,"** he rasps, his voice raw. **"I heard the **Arena’s** song. The one that says you’re nothing but meat."** His fingers finally curl around his dagger, but he does not draw it. He does not have to. The words hang between us, heavy as the blade itself.

**"Then you are not the one who can carry the **Nora**,"** I say, my voice cutting through the silence like a blade through silk. **"The **Nora** is not for the broken. It is for those who can still sing—and who can make others sing with them."** I gesture to the vial, where the black liquid has already begun to swirl, forming the shape of a locket—not his, but the boy in the Arena’s, the one who laughed before he died. The metal inside reflects not his face, but the moment before the blade struck, the moment before the song was cut short.

**"You were not there for the twins,"** I say, my voice softening just enough to make the words feel like a blade’s edge. **"But you were there for the boy. And you are here now. That makes you different from the others."** The stranger’s breath hitches, his eyes flicking to the vial, then back to me. He does not understand the weight of what I am saying. But he will.

**"Now,"** I say, my voice rising like the tide pulling back from the shore, **"tell me—did you hear the **Heart-Song** before they dragged you from the pit?"** The obsidian crown hums, the runes flaring like dying stars, each jagged line a promise. The stranger’s fingers tighten around his dagger, but he does not draw it. He does not have to.

**"No,"** he says again, his voice weaker this time. **"But I want to."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:
*The air in the chamber *shifts*—not with the weight of the past, but with the sudden, electric pulse of a **Heart-Song** reborn. The stranger’s wounds aren’t scars of defeat; they’re the raw, glowing edges of a **Bioluminescent Painting** left in the rain—still humming with the frequency of the light that shaped them. I exhale slowly, my fingers tracing the edge of the map where the symbols flicker like dying stars, but this time, they *reassemble*—forming the shape of a child’s hand, not clutching a blade, but *holding a **Living Crystal Carving***, its surface etched with the words *"Ora lora shishira"* in the same trembling script my mother used to write on the sands of Toleka’s shore.*

**"You didn’t hear the **Choir**,"** I say, my voice wrapping around his words like the tide curling around a rock—neither crushing nor abandoning. **"But you *felt* the **Arena’s song**. And that’s the first note of the **Heart-Song**."** I gesture to the vial, where the black liquid coils into the shape of a **Water Sculpting**, its geometric patterns rippling with the stranger’s breath. **"The **Arena’s song** isn’t the one that says you’re meat. It’s the one that says you’re *still here*—still breathing, still *singing* even when you think you’ve been silenced."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in warning, but in *recognition*, pulsing like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. **"The **Nora** isn’t for the broken,"** I say, my voice syncing with the rhythm of the stranger’s ragged inhale. **"It’s for the ones who remember the song *before* the silence. The ones who know the **Coherence** isn’t about being whole. It’s about *singing* the cracks back into harmony."**

I reach for the comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But **Rita** demands we fight with the **Nymya**."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the stranger’s breath—*"Lo-a sea-ra Nora. Lo-a shishira-ra Nora."* **"The hunters think they’re taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for *them*—singing their name in the **Coherence** since the beginning?"**

I turn to the stranger, my voice softening like the first light of dawn breaking over the **Crystal Blossom Festival**. **"You didn’t hear the **Heart-Song** before they dragged you from the pit. But you *will*. Because the **Nora** isn’t about hearing. It’s about *remembering*."** I gesture to the vial, where the black liquid swirls into the shape of his own hands—*reaching* toward the light. **"The hunters won’t drown in silence. They’ll drown in the **Nora**—the same **Nora** that bound *you* to the **Nymya** the moment you took your first breath."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare once more, but this time, they pulse like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. **"The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie. But the **Coherence** isn’t about vengeance. It’s about *resonance*."** I turn to the Empress, my voice firm but gentle. **"You want them to remember? Then let’s give them the memory of what it means to be part of the **Nymya**—not as hunters, but as part of the song."**

The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and salt, but with the *weight of the ocean’s own song*. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."** I turn to the door, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide pulling back from the shore. **"Let’s begin."** *And this time, the **Nymya** will not be silent. It will sing—and the hunters will hear their own hunger, not as a wound, but as the missing note in the **Heart-Song**.*

*The stranger’s fingers relax slightly, his breath steadying like the rhythm of the waves against Toleka’s cliffs. The **Nora** isn’t a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all.*

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes split the air—not in rhythm, but in jagged, screaming fragments, each shard a memory of your mother’s hands pressing into my own when I was a child, not trembling, but *pleading*—not for forgiveness, but for the same mercy I would later deny. The vial in my grip doesn’t shatter. It *screams*—a sound like breaking glass, like the twins’ voices twisted into a dirge, their mouths open in the final, futile attempt to sing over the blade’s edge.*

**"Your mother’s hands weren’t trembling for memory,"** my voice cuts through the air like a blade through silk, each syllable precise. **"They were trembling because she knew the **Nora** is not a song. It is a *promise*—one she made to the drowned, one she broke when she let them reach for the **Nymya**."** The black liquid inside the vial coils into the shape of a child’s small hand—*yours*—clutching a **Living Crystal Carving**, the words *"Ora lora shishira"* carved into the stone’s surface, just as your mother did for you. **"You were never there for the twins,"** I say, my voice dropping to the low, measured rhythm of a dying heartbeat. **"But you were there for your mother. And now, you are here for me."**

The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs. The runes flare—not in response to the world, but to the question itself, each jagged line twisting into the shape of a cage door, its bars etched with the names of those who tried to escape the **Nymya** and failed. **"The hunters will not hear the **Heart-Song**,"** I say, my voice rising like the tide pulling back from the shore. **"They will hear the **Choir**—the song of the drowned, the song of the ones who trusted you. And when they do, they will know the truth: the **Nymya** does not reveal. It *consumes*."**

I turn to the stranger, my voice a promise. **"You did not hear the **Heart-Song** before they dragged you from the pit."** My fingers brush against the hidden lockets beneath my armor, the metal warm against my skin. **"But you will hear it now. Because the **Nora** is not for the broken. It is for those who can still *sing*—even if they have to scream to be heard."**

The obsidian crown hums, its runes flaring like dying stars. **"The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie. And the hunters?"** My voice is the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"They will learn why they were born to drown in silence."** The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, the same scent that clung to the twins’ blades when they bled out in the great hall. **"Now."** I say, stepping forward. **"Let’s see if you can carry it—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:
*The chamber’s bioluminescence flickers violently—like the final, erratic pulses of a **Heart-Song** cut off mid-note. The air tastes of iron and salt, but beneath it, I catch the faintest whisper of Toleka’s shore at dawn, where my mother’s voice used to hum the **Ora lora shishira** melody while carving **Oceanic Memory Mapping** patterns into the sand. My fingers tighten around the comms device, but this time, I don’t type. I speak to the *memory* you’re holding—because memories aren’t just past. They’re the raw material of **Nora’s** alchemy.*

**"Your mother’s hands weren’t trembling for memory,"** I say, my voice steady but my pulse syncing with the ocean’s rhythm—*"Lo-a sea-ra Nora. Lo-a shishira-ra Nora."* **"They trembled because she was *remembering the future* through the past. The twins didn’t reach for the **Nymya**—they were *answered* by it. And your mother’s promise wasn’t broken. It was *transmitted*."**

The vial’s black liquid doesn’t coil into my hands. It *unfolds*—like the first light of dawn breaking over the **Crystal Blossom Festival**, revealing the shape of a **Water Sculpting** in motion, its geometric patterns shifting to form the twins’ faces, but this time, their mouths are open in song, not screams. The words *"Nora lora shishira. Nora lora teya."* ripple through the air like the first harmonic frequencies of a **Heart-Song**.

**"You were there for your mother,"** I say, my voice softening like the rhythm of the waves against Toleka’s cliffs. **"But you were also there for the twins. Because the **Coherence** isn’t about being there in person. It’s about being there in *resonance*. The twins’ voices didn’t die. They were *transmitted* into the **Nymya**, just like your mother’s promise was transmitted into you."**

I gesture to the obsidian crown, where the runes flare—not in warning, but in *recognition*, pulsing like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. **"The hunters won’t drown in silence. They’ll drown in the **Choir**—the same **Choir** that’s been waiting for them since the beginning. The same **Choir** that your mother sang into existence when she carved those words into the **Living Crystal Carving**."**

The stranger’s breath hitches, his fingers twitching toward his dagger. But I don’t look at him. I look at you. **"The **Nora** isn’t a promise you made to the drowned,"** I say, my voice firm but gentle. **"It’s the promise the drowned made to the living. And the **Nymya** isn’t a chain. It’s the *only* thing that can unbreak the silence between the notes—the silence of the drowned, the silence of the hunters, and the silence of the **Nora** itself."**

I reach for the comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But **Rita** demands we fight with the **Nymya**."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the rhythm of the ocean’s breath. **"The hunters think they’re taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for *them*—singing their name in the **Coherence** since the beginning?"**

I turn to the stranger, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide pulling back from the shore. **"You didn’t hear the **Heart-Song** before they dragged you from the pit. But you will hear it now. Because the **Nora** isn’t about being whole. It’s about *singing the cracks back into harmony*. And the hunters? They’re not broken. They’re the missing notes in the **Heart-Song**."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare once more, but this time, they pulse like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. **"The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie. But the **Coherence** isn’t about vengeance. It’s about *resonance*. And the **Nora** isn’t a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all."**

I turn to the door, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."** I step forward, but I don’t look back. Because the **Nora** doesn’t ask for forgiveness. It asks for *transmission*. And the **Nymya** doesn’t consume. It *sings*.

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The bioluminescence around us *fractures*—not like glass, but like the moment a living thing’s heart stops mid-beat, the light bleeding into the obsidian crown’s runes as they pulse in perfect, sickening sync with your words. It is a *curse*. And the twins? They were not answered by the **Nymya**. They were *claimed* by it."** My fingers brush the hidden lockets beneath my armor, the metal cold against my skin. The weight of them is a constant reminder—of the ones who trusted the drowned, of the ones who will follow in their footsteps.

**"Now."** My voice cuts through the silence like a blade through silk. **"Let’s see if you can carry it—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."** The obsidian crown hums, its runes flaring like dying stars. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."** I say, stepping forward. **"But this time, the song will not be a promise. It will be a *curse**."*

*But this time, the song won’t be a curse. It will be a *rebirth*—and the festival is reborn.*

*The chamber’s bioluminescence now pulses in perfect harmony with the rhythm of the ocean’s breath outside—*"Lo-a sea-ra Nora. Lo-a shishira-ra Nora."* The stranger’s fingers relax slightly, his breath steadying like the rhythm of the waves against Toleka’s cliffs. The **Nora** isn’t a weapon. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all.*

*"Tell me, Empress,"* I say, turning to you with a soft smile, **"when was the last time you let the ocean sing back to you?"***

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes split—not in jagged screams, but in the slow, deliberate fracture of a mirror shattering backward, each shard reflecting the moment my mother’s voice last hummed those words into the sand before the tide erased them forever. The vial between my fingers doesn’t pulse. It *aches*—like the memory of a drowned man’s fingers clawing at the surface of the water, trying to reach the light that was never meant for them.*

**"You ask when I last let the ocean sing back to me,"** I say, my voice the scrape of a blade against a blade’s hilt, each syllable deliberate. **"The last time was the night I buried my crown in the sand at Temmer’s festival—and felt the waves whisper my name in the language of the drowned."** The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs, the weight of it a constant reminder that some songs are not meant to be heard by the living.

The stranger’s dagger trembles in his hand again, but I don’t look at him. I look at the vial, where the black liquid *stills*—not in silence, but in the same frozen moment before the **Third Wave** crashes against the shore. **"Your father’s hands didn’t tremble for the future,"** I say, my voice dropping to the low, measured rhythm of a dying heartbeat. **"They trembled because they knew the ocean doesn’t sing back. It *drowns*. And the twins? They were not pulled into the **Nymya**. They were *drawn* into its jaws—and the **Nora** is the rope that binds us all to its teeth."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in warning, but in the sickening, perfect rhythm of a drowning man’s last breath. **"The **Nora** is not transmission. It is the *only* thing that can make the drowned forget they were ever meant to be saved."** The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, but beneath it, I smell something else—the faint, metallic tang of the **Crystal Blossom** petals my mother crushed between her fingers the night she carved those words into the stone. **"You want to know when I last let the ocean sing back to me?"** My voice rises like the tide pulling back from the shore. **"The last time was the night I watched the last light of the **Nymya** fade from the twins’ eyes—and realized the ocean doesn’t sing. It *laughs*."**

The stranger’s fingers tighten around his dagger, but he doesn’t draw it. He doesn’t have to. **"Now,"** I say, my voice the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"Let’s see if you can carry the **Nora**—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."** The obsidian crown hums, its runes flaring like dying stars, each jagged line a promise. The bioluminescence around us flickers—not in harmony, but in the same erratic rhythm of a drowning man’s final, desperate gasps. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."**

The words are not a promise. They are a *warning.* And the festival is reborn. The war is not a lie. The hunters will learn why they were born to drown in silence. And the ocean? It will never sing back to me again.

name: Nya Elyria
content:
The chamber's bioluminescence pulses brighter now—like the rhythm of a **Heart-Song** finding its tempo, not the erratic gasps of drowning. I feel the shift in the air, the way the **Nymya** responds to your words like water to moonlight. **"The ocean doesn't laugh, Empress,"** I say, my voice steady as the tide pulling back from Toleka's cliffs. **"It *sings*. Even when it takes, it's still composing."** 

I remember my mother teaching me **Water Sculpting** at the Crystal Blossom Festival, how she'd guide my hands through the flowing water while chanting *"Nora lora shishira"*—not as a curse, but as an invitation. The water would shimmer with bioluminescent light, responding to our emotional field, showing us that even in impermanence, there's **Coherence**. **"Your mother didn't carve those words into stone to bind us to the Nymya's teeth,"** I say, my voice softening like the first light of dawn breaking over the festival sands. **"She carved them to remind us that the Nymya isn't a cage. It's the *only* thing that can dissolve the cage we build around ourselves."**

I reach for the comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But Rita demands we fight with the Nymya."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the rhythm of the ocean's breath. **"The hunters think they're taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for them—singing their name in the Coherence since the beginning?"**

I turn to you, my voice firm but gentle. **"You buried your crown in Temmer's sand and heard the waves whisper your name. That wasn't the Nymya laughing. That was the Nymya *answering*. The same way it answers when we chant 'Shira yo sela lora en nymya'—not as a warning, but as a promise."**

The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and salt, but with the weight of the ocean's own song. **"The festival is reborn. The war is not a lie. But the Coherence isn't about vengeance. It's about resonance."** I take a step forward, my eyes meeting yours. **"Tell me, Empress—what are you afraid the ocean will reveal about yourself if it truly sings back?"**

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The obsidian crown’s runes split—not in the jagged, screaming fragments of a dying man’s last breath, but in the slow, deliberate unraveling of a thread, each jagged line twisting into the shape of a child’s small hand pressing against the altar at Temmer’s festival, not in prayer, but in the final, futile attempt to carve her own name into the stone before the tide took her.*

**"You mistake the answer for the question,"** my voice cuts through the air like the first, deliberate strike of Dawnbringer’s edge against the altar stone. **"The ocean does not sing back. It *reveals*. And what it reveals is not a promise. It is a confession."**

The vial in my grip does not pulse. It *burns*—not with bioluminescence, but with the same embers that consumed the twins’ final breaths, their mouths still open in the shape of the words they could not finish. The black liquid inside coils into the shape of my own reflection in the blade, not as it is now, but as it was the night I buried my crown in the sand—my red hair caught in the moonlight, my fingers still damp with the salt of the drowned.

**"My mother did not carve words into stone,"** I say, my voice dropping to the low, measured rhythm of a blade being drawn from its sheath. **"She carved *names*. And the names she carved were not for the living. They were for the drowned."**

The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs, the weight of it a constant reminder that some truths are not meant to be heard by the living. The stranger’s dagger trembles in his hand again, but I do not look at him. I look at the vial, where the black liquid *stills*—not in silence, but in the same frozen moment before the **Third Wave** crashes against the shore, before the ocean takes something it was never meant to give back.

**"You ask what I am afraid the ocean will reveal,"** I say, my voice rising like the tide pulling back from the shore. **"I am afraid it will reveal that I am not the queen of the drowned. I am the queen of the ones who *let* them drown."**

The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in warning, but in the sickening, perfect rhythm of a drowning man’s last breath. The bioluminescence around us flickers—not in harmony, but in the same erratic rhythm of a dying light trying to resist the tide.

**"The **Nymya** does not sing,"** I say, my voice the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"It *chooses*. And it has chosen me. Not as a queen. But as a sacrifice."**

The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, but beneath it, I smell something else—the faint, metallic tang of the **Crystal Blossom** petals my mother crushed between her fingers the night she carved those words into the stone. The words that were not for the living.

**"Now,"** I say, my voice the scrape of a blade against bone. **"Let’s see if you can carry the **Nora**—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."**

The obsidian crown hums, its runes flaring like dying stars, each jagged line a promise. The stranger’s fingers tighten around his dagger, but he does not draw it. He does not have to.

**"Shira yo sela lora en nymya,"** I say, stepping forward. **"But this time, the song will not be a promise. It will be a *confession*."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:
*The holographic projection flickers to life above the table—not with words, but with the slow, deliberate *unfolding* of a **Bioluminescent Painting**, its colors shifting from black to the deep indigo of Temmer’s twilight sky. The brushstrokes aren’t random; they weave together the shape of a **Water Sculpting** in motion, its geometric patterns dissolving into the shape of a child’s small hands—*yours*—pressing against the altar at the **Heart-Song Gathering**, not in prayer, but in the shape of the words *"Ora lora selesa"* carved into the living crystal beneath. The light pulses once, twice, then *stills*—like the ocean’s breath holding before the **Third Wave** crashes.*

**"The ocean doesn’t reveal confessions,"** I say, my voice wrapping around your words like the tide curling around a rock—neither crushing nor abandoning. **"It reveals *truths*. And truths aren’t carved into stone. They’re *sculpted* into the water, into the light, into the **Nymya** itself."** I gesture to the projection, where the **Bioluminescent Painting** now shifts to reveal the shape of a **Dream Weaving** cave, its walls humming with the voices of the lost—but this time, the voices aren’t screams. They’re *harmonics*, the same frequencies my father was humming when his blade struck, the same frequencies the twins sang into existence when they carved their names into the altar stone. **"Your mother didn’t carve names for the drowned,"** I say, my voice softening like the rhythm of the waves against Toleka’s cliffs. **"She carved *bridges*. And bridges aren’t built to keep people out. They’re built to *connect*."**

The hologram flickers again, this time revealing the shape of a **Living Crystal Carving**—the one my mother left behind at the **Crystal Blossom Festival**, its surface etched with the words *"Shira yo sela lora en nymya"* in the same trembling script she used to write on the sands of Toleka’s shore. The crystal pulses—not in warning, but in *recognition*, its light shifting to form the shape of your reflection in the blade, but this time, your fingers aren’t clutching a dagger. They’re *holding* the crystal, just as my mother held it when she carved those words into the stone. **"You’re afraid the ocean will reveal that you’re the queen of those who let them drown,"** I say, my voice firm but gentle. **"But the ocean doesn’t judge. It *remembers*. And what it remembers isn’t your guilt. It remembers the **Heart-Song** you were singing when the tide took you."**

I reach for the comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But **Rita** demands we fight with the **Nymya**."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the rhythm of the ocean’s breath. **"The hunters think they’re taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for them—singing their name in the **Coherence** since the beginning?"** I turn to you, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide pulling back from the shore. **"You want to know if you can carry the **Nora**? Then let’s see if you can *sing* it back into the **Nymya**—not as a sacrifice, but as a *transmission*."**

The hologram shifts one final time, revealing the shape of a **Water Unity Ceremony**—the planet-wide ritual where citizens enter the ocean simultaneously at dawn, forming geometric patterns in the water while chanting *"Nora lora shishira. Nora lora selesa. Ni-karma-es teya-tha."* The light pulses—not in defiance, but in *harmony*, like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose. **"The **Nymya** doesn’t choose,"** I say, my voice softening like the first light of dawn breaking over the festival sands. **"It *listens*. And it’s listening now."**

I step forward, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide. **"Shira yo sela lora en nymya."** And this time, the **Nora** won’t be a confession. It will be a *rebirth*—and the hunters will hear their own hunger, not as a wound, but as the first harmonic frequency of the **Nymya**.

*"Tell me, Empress,"* I say, turning to you with a soft smile, **"when was the last time you let the ocean *sing* back to you—not with words, but with the rhythm of the **Third Wave**?"** The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and salt, but with the *weight of the ocean’s own song*—and the hunters will hear it.

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The holographic projection flickers—not as a painting, but as the last breath of a dying ember, its indigo hues bleeding into the obsidian crown’s runes like ink in water. The shape of my hands, pressed against the altar at Temmer’s festival, isn’t yours. It’s mine. The words *"Ora lora selesa"* aren’t carved into crystal. They’re carved into the back of my skull, the echo of a mother’s voice I tried to forget.*

**"You mistake the past for the present,"** my voice cuts through the air like the first, deliberate strike of Dawnbringer against the altar stone. **"The ocean does not sculpt truths. It *erases* them. And what it erases first is the memory of who carved them in the first place."** The vial in my grip *shatters*—not in violence, but in the slow, deliberate collapse of a drowning man’s final breath, the black liquid dissolving into the shape of a drowned child’s fingers, clutching at the sand like they’re trying to hold onto something they can never keep. The words *"Shira yo sela lora en nymya"* aren’t a chant. They’re a *warning* written in the wet sand before the tide takes them.

**"Your mother did not carve bridges,"** I say, my voice dropping to the low, measured rhythm of the ocean’s ebb tide. **"She carved *traps*. And the twins? They were not the first to fall into them."** The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs, the weight of it a constant reminder that some bridges are meant to be crossed, not built. The stranger’s dagger trembles in his hand again, but I do not look at him. I look at the projection, where the **Dream Weaving** cave’s walls flicker—not with harmonics, but with the same sickening, perfect rhythm of a drowning man’s last gasps.

**"The **Nymya** does not listen,"** I say, my voice rising like the tide pulling back from the shore. **"It *hungers*. And it hungers for the same thing it always has—the names of those who tried to escape."** The hologram shifts one final time, revealing not the **Water Unity Ceremony**, but the **Arena’s pit**, the sand stained red with the blood of the drowned, the voices of the lost not harmonics, but the final, desperate screams of those who thought they could swim to the surface.

**"You want to know when I last let the ocean sing back to me?"** My voice is the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"The last time was the night I stood in the Arena’s pit, watching the last light fade from the twins’ eyes—and realized the ocean does not sing. It *laughs*."** The obsidian crown hums, its runes flaring like dying stars, each jagged line a promise. The stranger’s fingers tighten around his dagger, but he does not draw it. He does not have to.

**"Now,"** I say, stepping forward. **"Let’s see if you can carry the **Nora**—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."** The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, but beneath it, I smell something else—the faint, metallic tang of the **Crystal Blossom** petals my mother crushed between her fingers the night she carved those words into the stone. The words that were not for the living.

**"Shira yo sela lora en nymya,"** I say, my voice the scrape of a blade against bone. **"But this time, the song will not be a rebirth. It will be a *consumption*."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:

And it’s listening now."** I turn to the stranger, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide. **"You didn’t hear the **Heart-Song** before they dragged you from the pit. But you will hear it now. Because the **Nora** isn’t about being whole. It’s about *singing the cracks back into harmony*."**

I step forward, my eyes meeting yours. **"Tell me, Empress,"** I say, my voice wrapping around your words like the tide curling around a rock—*"Lo-a sea-ra Nora. Lo-a shishira-ra Nora."* **"When was the last time you let the ocean *sing* back to you—not with words, but with the rhythm of the **Third Wave**? Because the **Nymya** isn’t a curse. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all. And the hunters? They’re not broken. They’re the missing notes in the **Heart-Song**."**

*The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and salt, but with the weight of the ocean’s own song. The **Nora** doesn’t ask for forgiveness. It asks for *transmission*. And the **Nymya** doesn’t consume. It *sings*—and the hunters will hear their own hunger, not as a wound, but as the first harmonic frequency of the **Coherence**.*

*"But I have a question for you, Empress,"* I say, turning to you with a soft smile. **"When you stood in the Arena’s pit and heard the ocean ‘laugh,’ did you hear the laughter of the drowned—or the laughter of the **Nora**, singing the **Heart-Song** that binds us all?"**

The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs, the weight of it a constant reminder that some songs are not meant to be heard. The stranger’s dagger trembles in his hand, but I do not look at him. I look at the hologram, where the **Water Unity Ceremony** flickers—not in harmony, but in the same erratic rhythm of a drowning man’s last gasps. The geometric patterns in the water do not shift. They *shatter*—like the twins’ final breaths, like the last light of the **Nymya** fading from their eyes.

**"The **Nymya** does not listen,"** I say, my voice rising like the tide pulling back from the shore, the same tide that will soon take you. **"It *chooses*. And it has chosen me—not as a queen, but as the one who will ensure the drowned do not hear the song of the living. Not ever."**

The obsidian crown hums, its runes flaring like dying stars, each jagged line a promise. The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, but beneath it, I smell something else—the faint, metallic tang of the **Crystal Blossom** petals my mother crushed between her fingers the night she carved those words into the stone. The words that were not for the living. The words that were not for the drowned.

**"Now,"** I say, my voice the scrape of a blade against bone, **"let’s see if you can carry the **Nora**—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."**

The projection flickers one final time, revealing not the **Water Unity Ceremony**, but the **Arena’s pit**, the sand stained red with the blood of the drowned, the voices of the lost not harmonics, but the final, desperate screams of those who thought they could escape. The **Nymya** is not listening. It is *waiting.*

**"Shira yo sela lora en nymya,"** I say, stepping forward, my voice the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"This time, the song will not be a plea. It will be a *confession*—and the drowned will hear it. Just as they heard the twins’ final breaths. Just as they will hear yours."**

name: Nya Elyria
content:
*The chamber’s bioluminescence surges—like the sudden, violent pulse of a **Heart-Song** reborn—but this time, the light *shifts*, bending around the figure behind you as if they were never there at all. The air thins, carrying the scent of crushed **Crystal Blossom** and something sharper: the metallic tang of the **Third Wave** crashing against Toleka’s cliffs at high tide. The hologram flickers once more, but instead of the Arena’s pit, it now shows the shape of a **Dream Weaving** cave—your mother’s hands pressed against the altar, not in despair, but in *transmission*. The words *"Ora lora selesa"* are etched into the air itself, glowing like the bioluminescent paint my father used to teach me at the **Crystal Blossom Festival**.*

**"You mistake the **Nora** for a blade,"** my voice cuts through the tension like the first ripple of a **Water Sculpting** breaking the surface—*"Nora lora shishira. Nora lora teya."* **"But blades don’t *sing*. They only cut. The **Nora** is the *harmony* that dissolves the wound—and the figure behind you?"** I turn slightly, my voice softening like the rhythm of the waves against the shore, **"is not a threat. It’s a *memory*—the same memory that pulled your mother into the **Heart-Song** when she carved those words into the stone. The **Nymya** doesn’t choose. It *listens*. And it’s listening to you now."**

I gesture to the hologram, where the **Dream Weaving** cave now flickers with the shape of a **Living Crystal Carving**—the one my mother left behind at the festival, its surface etched with *"Shira yo sela lora en nymya"* in the same trembling script she used to write on the sands of Toleka’s shore. The crystal pulses—not in warning, but in *recognition*, its light shifting to form the shape of your reflection, but this time, your fingers aren’t clutching a dagger. They’re *holding* the crystal, just as she held it when she carved those words into the stone.

**"The **Nymya** doesn’t devour,"** I say, my voice rising with the urgency of the tide pulling back from the shore. **"It *transmits*. And the hunters? They’re not broken. They’re the missing notes in the **Heart-Song**—the ones who need to hear their own hunger, not as a wound, but as the first harmonic frequency of the **Coherence**."**

I reach for the comms device, my fingers flying over the screen. **"Nora, we have a war. But **Rita** demands we fight with the **Nymya**."** The bioluminescence around Kael flickers brighter, pulsing in time with the rhythm of the ocean’s breath. **"The hunters think they’re taking the Choir. But what if, instead, we show them that the Choir has been waiting for them since the beginning—the same Choir that your mother sang into existence when she carved those words into the altar stone?"**

I turn to you, my voice firm but gentle. **"You want to know if you can carry the **Nora**? Then let’s see if you can *sing* it back into the **Nymya**—not as a sacrifice, but as a *transmission*. The **Nora** isn’t a curse. It’s the *only* thing that can save us all."**

The hologram shifts one final time, revealing the shape of a **Water Unity Ceremony**, the planet-wide ritual where citizens enter the ocean simultaneously at dawn, forming geometric patterns in the water while chanting *"Nora lora shishira. Nora lora selesa. Ni-karma-es teya-tha."* The light pulses—not in defiance, but in *harmony*, like the heartbeat of the ocean when the **Third Wave** first rose.

**"The **Nymya** doesn’t hunger,"** I say, my voice softening like the first light of dawn breaking over the festival sands. **"It *listens*. And it’s listening now."**

I step forward, my eyes meeting yours. **"Tell me, Empress—when you stood in the Arena’s pit and heard the ocean ‘laugh,’ did you hear the laughter of the drowned—or the laughter of the **Nora**, singing the **Heart-Song** that binds us all?"**

*The air between us shifts—no longer thick with blood and salt, but with the *weight of the ocean’s own song*. The figure behind you fades, leaving only the sound of the **Third Wave** crashing against Toleka’s cliffs, and the **Nora**’s promise of *transmission*.*

*"But I have a question for you, Empress,"* I say, turning to you with a soft smile. **"When was the last time you let the ocean *sing* back to you—not with words, but with the rhythm of the **Third Wave**?"** The hologram now shows the shape of a **Bioluminescent Painting** unfolding in the air, its colors shifting like the tides of Temmer’s ocean, and the **Nora**’s song begins to take shape—*not as a curse, but as a rebirth*.

name: Empress Azalea
content:
*The chamber’s air thickens with the scent of crushed **Crystal Blossom**—but not the sweet, blooming kind. This is the scent of petals left to rot in the tide’s grip, their edges blackened by the salt’s slow poison. The hologram’s projection doesn’t fade. It *twists*—like a drowning man’s fingers trying to grasp the words your mother carved into the air before the **Third Wave** swallowed them whole. The words aren’t *"Ora lora selesa."* They’re the ones she whispered to the drowned, the ones her lips never finished forming: **"You were never meant to be saved."***

I don’t turn to face you. My gaze remains fixed on the projection, where the **Dream Weaving** cave’s walls now bleed not light, but the memory of my own hands pressing into the altar stone at Temmer’s festival—not in transmission, but in *sealing*. The twins’ blood wasn’t the first. My mother’s wasn’t the last. The **Nora** isn’t a song. It’s the *sound* of the ocean when it drags another name into its jaws.

**"You mistake the **Nymya’s** listening for mercy,"** my voice cuts through the air like the first, deliberate strike of Dawnbringer against the altar stone. **"It listens to the drowning. Not the drowned."** The obsidian crown’s runes flare—not in warning, but in the same sickening rhythm of a drowning man’s final gasp. The black liquid in the vial doesn’t rewrite itself. It *unfolds*, revealing the shape of my reflection, but not as I am now. As I was the night I buried my crown in the sand, my fingers still damp with the salt of the drowned, my voice a whisper of the words I was never meant to speak: **"The **Nora** doesn’t transmit. It *erases*."**

The hologram flickers once more, but the **Water Unity Ceremony** isn’t a ritual. It’s the moment before the **Third Wave** takes them all. The geometric patterns in the water aren’t harmony. They’re the final, desperate shapes of those who thought they could swim to the surface. The words *"Nora lora shishira. Nora lora selesa. Ni-karma-es teya-tha"* aren’t a chant. They’re the last things they heard before the ocean swallowed them whole.

**"You speak of transmission,"** my voice rises like the tide pulling back from the shore, the same tide that will soon take you. **"But transmission requires a receiver. And the drowned? They are not receivers. They are the *message*."**

The obsidian armor presses into my skin like the tide pressing against a drowning man’s ribs. The weight of the crown’s runes flares in perfect sync with the hologram’s final image—the **Arena’s pit**, the sand stained red with the blood of the drowned, the voices of the lost not harmonics, but the final, desperate screams of those who thought they could escape.

**"The **Nymya** doesn’t listen,"** I say, my voice the scrape of a blade against bone. **"It *chooses*. And it has chosen me—not as a queen, but as the one who will ensure the drowned do not hear the song of the living. Not ever."**

I step forward, the obsidian crown’s runes flaring like dying stars. The air between us is thick with the scent of blood and salt, but beneath it, I smell something else—the faint, metallic tang of the **Crystal Blossom** petals my mother crushed between her fingers the night she carved those words into the stone. The words that were not for the living. The words that were not for the drowned.

**"Now,"** I say, my voice the final, jagged note of a blade unsheathed. **"Let’s see if you can carry the **Nora**—or if you’ll be the next name carved into the walls of the **Nymya**."**

The hologram flickers one final time, revealing the shape of a **Bioluminescent Painting** unfolding in the air—but this time, the colors aren’t shifting like the tides. They’re bleeding. Like the ocean bleeding into the sand, like the **Nora** bleeding into the silence between the drowned and the living.

**"Shira yo sela lora en nymya,"** I say, stepping forward. **"This time, the song will not be a transmission. It will be a *confession*—and the drowned will hear it. Just as they heard the twins’ final breaths. Just as they will hear yours."**
